channel.title: Hacker News - English
channel.description: Hacker News articles summarized and translated to English

item.title: Reverse engineering Codex CLI to get GPT-5-Codex-Mini to draw me a pelican
item.description:
More recent articles Video + notes on upgrading a Datasette plugin for the latest 1. 0 alpha, with help from uv and OpenAI Codex CLI - 6th November 2025 Code research projects with async coding agents like Claude Code and Codex - 6th November 2025.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 2 Comments:

djmips:

How long before large language models are specifically trained on drawing pelicans riding a bicycle. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

f311a:

Installing Rust projects is usually as simple as calling `cargo install`. No need to wait for 5-30 minutes until LLM figures this out.

People are delegating way too much to LLMs. In turn, this makes your own research or problem-solving skills less sharp.

item.title: Boring Company fined nearly $500K after it dumped drilling fluids into manholes
item.description:
CCWRD says that “TBC staff refused” to stop dumping the fluids when inspectors told them to stop. 14, inspectors returned and again instructed Boring Company employees to stop discharging. AdvertisementAdvertisementAdvertisementAdvertisementIn a letter Boring sent to.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 8 Comments:

rkagerer:

Separate from the fines, why doesn't CCWRD litigate to get their cleanup costs back?

CCWRD says that its crews ultimately had to clean 12 cubic yards of “drilling mud, drilling spoils, and miscellaneous solid waste” from one of its sewage treatment facilities due to Boring’s discharges across two of its project sites

ProofHouse:

Honestly this is extra repulsive coming from the richest man in the world

binary132:

Some of these companies seem to have figured out that you can just do things and get away with it if you don’t mind paying a few fines (maybe “fees” would be a better term??)

bawolff:

How is that only a $500,000 fine???

Stopping when inspectors are there only to restart once they leave is willful enough that you wonder why this doesn't go into criminal liability?

AlexandrB:

The Boring Company seems like a total nothingburger at this point. The Las Vegas Loop is not particularly impressive and it's taking a long time to expand it. Nothing about this feels revolutionary or even evolutionary. Just novelty.

The fact that Teslas can't navigate autonomously even in these controlled, enclosed environments is also quite embarrassing.

sharkjacobs:

Indignation is anger plus self righteousness. Social media companies have found that they see the best return on content which is both shocking and serves users' confirmation bias.

"This thing you already hate is just as bad as you already thought."

Do companies run by Elon Musk violate ethical and environmental regulations much more often than other similar companies, or does it just seem that way as a casual news reader because it is more worthwhile for outlets to publish a story when it happens?

I'm open to the idea that they really are worse, it would be very "on brand" for Musk, but I wish I had a sense of the numbers

consumer451:

There was an amazing YouTube poop format satire video with Musk saying: ~"There are no consequences. Life has no meaning."

I can no longer find it. If anyone else can, it might be nice to link here.

ChrisArchitect:

Related:

Boring Company cited for almost 800 environmental violations in Las Vegas

https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=45540585

item.title: How Airbus Took Off
item.description:
Boeing 737 and Airbus A320 family deliveries over time. Airbus prevailed because it was the least European version of a European industrial strategy project ever. Amid this gloomy backdrop, European governments concluded that their industry’s future depended on cooperation.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 4 Comments:

quacked:

> Airbus prevailed because it was the least European version of a European industrial strategy project ever. It put its customer first, was uninterested in being seen as European, had leadership willing to risk political blowback in the pursuit of a good product, and operated in a unique industry

This really buries the lede, given that over the past 40 years Boeing sawed off both its own feet and drank cyanide. Total cultural change at the executive level that prioritized returns over good engineering.

ggm:

The chart of Airbus vs Boeing hull sales would have benefited from a center line Airbus above boeing below style.

Stacked charts for two families work better that way than stack from baseline.

ma2rten:

Europe is quite conservative, in the sense that they would not invest billions into an unproven venture. It makes sense that it would excel at an industry that requires putting safety above everything.

dandersch:

  There was also residual suspicion of European industry among US airliners. [...]
  Against this backdrop, Airbus did everything it could to deemphasize its European heritage as it toured the US.
The European tech industry on the other hand managed to curb that suspicion by becoming a complete non-threat.

item.title: Show HN: Geofenced chat communities anyone can create
IRIX Introduction
item.description:
Beginning with IRIX 6. The last IRIX release is IRIX 6. Indigo Indigo with R4x00 CPUs can run IRIX 6.

HN Discussion

Top 1 Comments:

29athrowaway:

It's what they use in Jurassic Park.

The 3D file manager is fsn.
